maml:description.maml:para: Uploads a local file to a blob in Windows Azure blob storage.

The Add-Blob cmdlet uploads a local file to a blob in the specified container. The file can be uploaded either as a block blob or as a page blob. If the specified container does not exist in the blob storage, it will be created.
Blob type (block or page).
Specifies the path of the content to be uploaded.
Specifies the name of the container where the content will be uploaded.
Specifies the connection string to connect with the storage.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Blob type (block or page).
Specifies the path of the content to be uploaded.
Specifies the name of the container where the content will be uploaded.
Specifies the connection string to connect with the storage.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example uploads the content of the file "c:\images\tree.jpg" to a block blob in the "images" container.
This example uploads the content of the file "c:\images\tree.jpg" to a page blob in the "images" container.

maml:description.maml:para: Upload a service certificate for the specified hosted service.
Hosted Service Name.
Certificate to deploy. You can specify the file path location (*.cer, *. pfx, etc) or an X509Certificate object.
Certificate password.
Specifies a custom binding used to access the management service (Advanced).
The maximum string content length quota used to access the management service (Advanced).
Specifies an alternate service endpoint for the management service (Advanced).

Specifies your account subscription ID. When you create a Windows Azure subscription, it is uniquely identified by a subscription ID. You can retrieve this ID from the Windows Azure Management Portal.

The account management certificate associated with your subscription. Management certificates are X.509 certificates that are saved as a .cer file and uploaded to the Windows Azure Management Portal. The certificate including its private key needs to be installed in your local machine.

Configure a relying party application.

Relying party applications are your websites, applications, and services for which you want to use ACS to implement federated authentication. Relying party applications consume claims from identity providers to make authentication and authorization decisions.

Removes blobs from one or more containers in Windows Azure blob storage.

The Clear-Container cmdlet removes the contents of one or more containers in blob storage. Multiple containers can be cleared in a single operation by specifying a list of container names. A Filter parameter allows removing only a subset of the blobs in a container by specifying a blob name prefix.
Specifies one or more containers to clear. You can specify multiple container names (separated by commas).
Specifies a filter to selectively remove only blobs whose name starts with the chosen prefix.
Blobs with 'last modified' date property greater or equal than this date will be deleted.
Blobs with 'last modified' date property less or equal than this date will be deleted.
Specifies the connection string to connect with the storage.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.

Specifies a filter to selectively remove only blobs whose name starts with the chosen prefix.

Blobs with 'last modified' date property less or equal than this date will be deleted (UTC time zone).

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes all the blobs in the “images” container.
This command removes all the blobs in the “images” container whose name starts with the prefix “sports”.
This command clears the content of all the containers whose name starts with the prefix “wad-“, typically to clear all diagnostic data.
This command removes all the blobs in the “images” container whose last modified property is between From and To dates, expressed as a local time.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes Windows Azure Diagnostic Infrastructure log data from a storage account.

The Clear-InfrastructureLog cmdlet clears infrastructure log data exported by Windows Azure Diagnostics to the WADDiagnosticInfrastructureLogsTable of the specified storage account.A subset of the data available can be removed by specifying a period of time for which to clear data.
The deployment ID.

Specifies the start of the period for which to clear data expressed as local time. Use the FromUtc parameter to express the start of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to clear data expressed as local time. Use the ToUtc parameter to express the end of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.
The deployment ID.

Specifies the start of the period for which to clear data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the From parameter to express the start of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to clear data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the To parameter to express the end of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

The deployment ID.

Specifies the start of the period for which to clear data expressed as local time. Use the FromUtc parameter to express the start of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to clear data expressed as local time. Use the ToUtc parameter to express the end of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the start of the period for which to clear data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the From parameter to express the start of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to clear data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the To parameter to express the end of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: Get- Deployment -SubscriptionId $subId -Certificate $cert -Slot Production -ServiceName MyTodo | Clear-InfrastructureLog -FromUtc "2011-09-09 00:00:00" -ToUtc "2011-09-09 23:59:59" -StorageAccountName mytododata -StorageAccountKey $key

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command clears Windows Azure Diagnostic Infrastructure log data for the deployment running in the Production slot of the MyTodo hosted service for the period of time starting from "2011-09-09 00:00:00" until "2011-09-09 23:59:59", expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

maml:description.maml:para: Removes Windows Azure Diagnostics performance data from a storage account.

Downloads Windows Azure Diagnostic Infrastructure log data from a storage account.

The infrastructure log contains information about the diagnostic monitor and configuration changes and can be useful for troubleshooting issues involving the diagnostic monitor.The Get-InfrastructureLog cmdlet downloads Windows Azure Diagnostic Infrastructure log data stored in the WADDiagnosticInfrastructureLogsTable of the specified storage account. The downloaded data is written to a local disk file in CSV format.
Specifies the path to a local file where to store the data downloaded from the storage account. If this parameter is not provided, the data is written to the PowerShell pipeline instead.
Specifies the name of the role for which to download data. If this parameter is not specified, infrastructure log data is downloaded for all roles in the deployment.

Specifies the start of the period for which to download data expressed as local time. Use the FromUtc parameter to express the start of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to download data expressed as local time. Use the ToUtc parameter to express the end of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the ID of the deployment for which to download data. Each deployment is identified by a deployment ID that can be retrieved from the Management Portal or using the Get-Deployment cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.
Specifies the path to a local file where to store the data downloaded from the storage account. If this parameter is not provided, the data is written to the PowerShell pipeline instead.
Specifies the name of the role for which to download data. If this parameter is not specified, infrastructure log data is downloaded for all roles in the deployment.

Specifies the start of the period for which to download data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the From parameter to express the start of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to download data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the To parameter to express the end of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.

maml:description.maml:para: Downloads Windows Azure Diagnostics performance data from a storage account.

The Get-PerfmonLog cmdlet downloads Windows Azure diagnostic data from performance counters stored in the WADPerformanceCountersTable of the specified storage account. A subset of the data available can be downloaded by specifying the name of a counter to retrieve, which may include wildcards, and a period of time for which to retrieve data.The downloaded data is written to local disk files (one file for each role instance) in either CSV or BLG (binary) format and can be loaded by Performance Monitor for analysis.Diagnostic data is not permanently stored unless you transfer the data to the Windows Azure storage emulator or to Windows Azure storage.
Specifies the name of the performance counter for which to download data. The name of the performance counter can include wildcards, for example, “\ASP.NET\*” or “\Processor(?)\Interrupts/sec”.
The format of the output file. Only BLG and CSV formats are supported. The default value is CSV.
Specifies the path to a local directory where to store the data downloaded from the storage account. If this parameter is not provided, the data is written to the PowerShell pipeline instead.
Specifies the name of the role for which to download data. If this parameter is not specified, performance data is downloaded for all roles in the deployment.

Specifies the start of the period for which to download data expressed as local time. Use the FromUtc parameter to express the start of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to download data expressed as local time. Use the ToUtc parameter to express the end of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the ID of the deployment for which to download data. Each deployment is identified by a deployment ID that can be retrieved from the Management Portal or using the Get-Deployment cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.
Specifies the name of the performance counter for which to download data. The name of the performance counter can include wildcards, for example, “\ASP.NET\*” or “\Processor(?)\Interrupts/sec”.
The format of the output file. Only BLG and CSV formats are supported. The default value is CSV.
Specifies the path to a local directory where to store the data downloaded from the storage account. If this parameter is not provided, the data is written to the PowerShell pipeline instead.
Specifies the name of the role for which to download data. If this parameter is not specified, performance data is downloaded for all roles in the deployment.

Specifies the start of the period for which to download data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the From parameter to express the start of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to download data expressed using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Use the To parameter to express the end of the period as a local time. Windows Azure Diagnostic tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the ID of the deployment for which to download data. Each deployment is identified by a deployment ID that can be retrieved from the Management Portal or using the Get-Deployment cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Deployment -SubscriptionId $subId -Certificate $cert -Slot Production -ServiceName MyTodo | Get-PerfmonLog -LocalPath “c:\perfdata” -Format BLG -From "2011-09-09 00:00" -StorageAccountName mytododata -StorageAccountKey $key

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command downloads performance counter data for the deployment running in the Production slot of the MyTodo hosted service to a directory in the local disk named “C:\perfdata” for the period starting from "2011-09-09 00:00:00" until the current time, expressed as a local time. The data is stored in BLG format. The data is retrieved from the mytododata storage account.

Retrieves persisted Windows Azure subscription configuration settings.

The Get-Subscription cmdlet retrieves common subscription settings stored in the user’s profile, including subscription ID and management certificate information, as well as connection information for one or more Windows Azure storage accounts.

Managing Windows Azure services requires a number of common parameters including the ID and the management certificate for a subscription, in addition to storage account settings. These common settings can be persisted to a file in the user’s profile. The Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlets can reference the information stored in the subscription data file and use it to provide default values for certain parameters.

Multiple subscriptions data sets are supported and identified by a subscription name. Use the Import-Subscription and Set-Subscription cmdlet to store common settings for each subscription to be managed.

During a session, use the Select-Subscription cmdlet to choose which subscription data set is used by the cmdlets to retrieve subscription and storage account parameter information. The cmdlets use the settings in the selected subscription unless explicitly overriden by parameters in the command line.
Retrieves the configuration settings for the subscription identified by this name. You can only specify one of the following parameters: Default, Current, or SubscriptionName.
If a subscription name is not provided, the cmdlet lists every subscription currently stored in the subscription data file.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is read from a default file in the user's profile.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is read from a default file in the user's profile.

If this parameter is specified, returns the subscription that has been designated as the default subscription. You can only specify one of the following parameters: Default, Current, or SubscriptionName.
A default subscription is automatically selected whenever the PowerShell session starts. To designate the default subscription, use the Set-Subscription cmdlet.
If this parameter is specified, returns the subscription that is currently selected. You can only specify one of the following parameters: Default, Current, or SubscriptionName.
The Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlets retrieve default settings for their parameters from the information stored in the current subscription.
To select a subscription and make it current, use the Select-Subscription cmdlet.

If this parameter is specified, returns the subscription that has been designated as the default subscription. You can only specify one of the following parameters: Default, Current, or SubscriptionName.
A default subscription is automatically selected whenever the PowerShell session starts. To designate the default subscription, use the Set-Subscription cmdlet.

The Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlets retrieve default settings for their parameters from the information stored in the current subscription.
To select a subscription and make it current, use the Select-Subscription cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Downloads Windows Event log data from a storage account.

The Get-WAEventLog cmdlet downloads Windows Event log data exported by Windows Azure Diagnostics to the WADWindowsEventLogsTable of the specified storage account. The downloaded data is written to a local disk file in CSV format.A subset of the data available can be downloaded by specifying a period of time for which to retrieve data.Diagnostic data is not permanently stored unless you transfer the data to the Windows Azure storage emulator or to Windows Azure storage.
Specifies the path to a local file where to store the data downloaded from the storage account. If this parameter is not provided, the data is written to the PowerShell pipeline instead.
Specifies the name of the role for which to download data. If this parameter is not specified, performance data is downloaded for all roles in the deployment.

Specifies the start of the period for which to download data expressed as local time. Use the FromUtc parameter to express the start of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.

Specifies the end of the period for which to download data expressed as local time. Use the ToUtc parameter to express the end of the period using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Windows Azure Diagnostics tables use UTC to store time data.
Specifies the ID of the deployment for which to download data. Each deployment is identified by a deployment ID that can be retrieved from the Management Portal or using the Get-Deployment cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

maml:description.maml:para: Imports Windows Azure subscription data from a .publishsettings file downloaded from the management portal.

The Import-Subscription cmdlet imports publish settings and credentials from a file that you download from the Windows Azure management portal. These settings include the subscription ID, management certificate, and service endpoint for one or more subscriptions associated to the user account used to sign in to the portal. To download the .publishsettings file, go to https://windows.azure.com/download/publishprofile.aspx.

The cmdlet imports the subscription settings to the specified subscription data file and installs the management certificate associated with each subscription in the current user's personal certificate store.
Be aware that the .publishsettings file contains sensitive information and should be deleted or stored in a safe location once this process is complete.
Path to the .publishsettings file downloaded from the Windows Azure Management Portal.
To download the .publishsettings file, go to https://windows.azure.com/download/publishprofile.aspx.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is imported into a default file in the user's profile.
Path to the .publishsettings file downloaded from the Windows Azure Management Portal.
To download the .publishsettings file, go to https://windows.azure.com/download/publishprofile.aspx.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is imported into a default file in the user's profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new affinity group in a specified data center location for the given subscription.

The New-AffinityGroup cmdlet creates a new affinity group in your subscription. An affinity group groups your services together in Windows Azure data centers for optimal performance. Affinity groups are defined at the subscription level and are available to any subsequent hosted services or storage accounts that you create. You can associate services with an affinity group as you create them.
A name for the new affinity group that is unique to the subscription.
A label for the affinity group. The label may be up to 100 characters in length.
A description for the affinity group. The description may be up to 1024 characters in length.
Required if AffinityGroup is not specified. The geographical location of the data center where the affinity group will be created.
Specifies a custom binding used to access the management service (Advanced).

A name for the new affinity group that is unique to the subscription.

Creates a new deployment.

The New-Deployment cmdlet creates a new deployment based on the package/configuration files. There should not be an existing deployment with the same name nor in the same slot when executing this command.
Deployment slot (Staging | Production). If not specified, Production slot will be used by default.
Package location. This parameter should have the path or URI to a .cspkg in blob storage whose storage account is part of the same subscription/project.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new hosted service in Windows Azure.

The New-HostedService cmdlet creates a hosted service in your Windows Azure subscription. A hosted service is a service that runs your code in the Windows Azure environment. You can create, deploy, run, suspend, and delete hosted services in your subscription using the Windows Azure Platform PowerShell Cmdlets.

Specifies a name for the administrator account login.

Specifies a password for the administrator account login. A password must be at least 8 characters long and contain at least three of the four following classes: Latin uppercase letter (A-Z), Latin lowercase letter (a-z), Base 10 digits (0-9), Non-alphanumeric characters such as: exclamation point (!), dollar sign ($), number sign (#), or percent (%). Further, it may not contain any three consecutive characters of the creator login.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes persisted Windows Azure subscription configuration settings for a specified subscription.

Managing Windows Azure services requires a number of common parameters including the ID and management certificate for a subscription, in addition to storage account settings. These common settings can be persisted to a file in the user’s profile. The Remove-Subcription cmdlet allows you to remove all the settings associated with the specified subscription.
Specify to remove any configuration settings associated with this subscription.
Specifies the path to a file where the subscription data is stored. This parameter is optional. If it is not provided, the subscription data is removed from a default file in the user's profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Requests a reboot or reimage of a single role instance or for all role instances in a specific role.
The Reset-RoleInstance cmdlet requests a reboot or a reimage of a role instance that is running in a deployment.

This operation executes asynchronously. To determine whether the Management service has finished processing the request, call the Get-OperationStatus cmdlet with the operation ID returned by Reset-RoleInstance, and optionally wait for completion by specifying the –WaitToComplete parameter.

When you reboot a role instance, Windows Azure takes the instance offline, restarts the underlying operating system for that instance, and brings the instance back online. Any data that is written to the local disk is persisted across reboots. Any data that is in-memory is lost.
Reimaging a role instance results in different behavior depending on the type of role:

- For a web or worker role, when the role is reimaged, Windows Azure takes the role offline and writes a fresh installation of the Windows Azure guest operating system to the virtual machine. The role is then brought back online.
- For a VM role, when the role is reimaged, Windows Azure takes the role offline, reapplies the custom image that you provided for it, and brings the role back online.

Windows Azure attempts to maintain data in any local storage resources when the role is reimaged; however, in case of a transient hardware failure, the local storage resource may be lost. If your application requires that this data be persisted in a guaranteed fashion, it's recommended that you write it to a durable data source, such as a Windows Azure drive.
Any data that is written to a local directory other than that defined by the local storage resource will be lost when the role is reimaged.

maml:description.maml:para: Downloads blobs from one or more containers in Windows Azure blob storage and saves them to local disk.

The Save-Container cmdlet downloads and saves the contents of one or more containers in blob storage. Each blob is saved to a separate disk file named after the corresponding blob. The files are stored inside folders that are created based on the directory structure implied by the use of the path delimiter (/) in the blob’s name, replicating the hierarchical directory structure of the blobs stored in the container to the specified path in your local disk. New child folders are created as needed. Multiple containers can be downloaded in a single operation by specifying a list of container names.A Filter parameter allows retrieving and saving only a subset of the blobs in the container by specifying a blob name prefix.
Specifies one or more containers to download. You can specify multiple container names (separated by commas).

Specifies the path to a folder in the local disk where the blobs in the container are downloaded. Each container specified in the ContainerName parameter is downloaded to this path and stored in a separate folder based on the name of the container.
Specifies a filter to download and save only blobs whose name starts with the chosen prefix.
Specifies the connection string to connect with the storage.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Specifies that the target of the operation is the local storage emulator. You can specify UseDevelopmentStorage or StorageAccountKey and StorageAccountName parameters, but not both.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.

maml:description.maml:para: Selects the current Windows Azure subscription default settings.

Subscription data sets contain common settings for a Windows Azure subscription that are stored in the user’s profile, including subscription ID and management certificate information, as well as connection information for one or more Windows Azure storage accounts. The Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlets can reference the information stored in the subscription data set and use it to provide default values for certain parameters.

Multiple subscriptions data sets are supported and identified by a subscription name. The Select-Subscription cmdlet selects which subscription data set is used by the Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlets to retrieve subscription and storage account parameter information.
The name of the subscription data set that the Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlets should use to read default values.
Use the Set-Subscription and Import-Subscription cmdlets to store settings for one or more subscriptions.

If no subscription is currently selected, the necessary information must be explicitly provided in the command line when executing any Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Configures and persists common Windows Azure subscription settings.

The Set-Subscription cmdlet configures common settings including subscription ID, management certificate, and storage account credentials and it stores them in a subscription data file in the user’s profile or in a user specified file.

Multiple subscriptions data sets are supported and identified by a subscription name. The Set-Subscription cmdlet stores subscription and storage account settings and associates them with the specified subscription.

Use the Set-Subscription cmdlet to store the subscription ID, management certificate, and service endpoint associated with a subscription. The management certificates specified for a subscription must be accessible and installed locally in the user or the local machine’s personal certificate store. The service endpoint is the Windows Azure management API endpoint for the target environment. Custom service endpoints are supported and can be different for each configured subscription.

Each subscription data set can contain connection information for one or more Windows Azure storage accounts. Accounts can be added to a subscription by specifying either a connection string for the account or its account name and key, and optionally, the blob, table, and queue service endpoints for the service. Custom storage service endpoints are supported and can be specified either in the connection string or as individual settings. All connection information is stored in encrypted form in the subscription data file.

If a subscription is designated as the default subscription, it is automatically made current when starting a PowerShell session or executing a script. To set the default subscription, use the –DefaultSubscription parameter and specify the name of the subscription to designate as default. The default subscription setting can be cleared by specifying the –NoDefaultSubscription switch parameter.

Any cmdlet that makes uses of a storage account can retrieve the credentials from one of the registered accounts in the current subscription. Each subscription can be assigned a default storage account, which is the account that will be used if no explicit storage account parameters are provided in the command line. To use a different storage account, you must specify its name as the value of the –StorageAccountName parameter of the corresponding cmdlet. The necessary connection information is retrieved from the current subscription provided the chosen storage account has been previously added to its settings.

To specify a default storage account, use the –DefaultStorageAccount parameter and specify the name of the account to be used. A default storage account setting can be reset by specifying the –NoDefaultStorageAccount switch parameter.
To remove a storage account previously added to the subscription, use the –RemoveStorageAccount parameter and specify its name.

All the parameters required to initialize a subscription are optional. Whenever a Windows Azure PowerShell Cmdlet is executed, it retrieves its default settings from the current subscription data. Any setting that is not available in the subscription needs to be specified as an explicit command line parameter.
To select a subscription and make it current, use the Select-Subscription cmdlet.
The name of the subscription data set that will be updated.
ID of the subscription. Each Windows Azure subscription is uniquely identified by a subscription ID. You can retrieve this ID from the Windows Azure Management Portal.
The account management certificate associated with the subscription. Management certificates are X.509 certificates that are saved as a .cer file and uploaded to the Windows Azure Management Portal.
The certificate including its private key needs to be installed in the local machine, either in the current user or the local machine’s personal certificate store.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets Windows Azure Storage Analytics properties for a storage account.

The Set-StorageServicePropertiesForAnalytics cmdlet configures the Windows Azure Storage Analytics properties for a storage account including configuration options for logging and metrics, such as setting retention policies, selecting what data to store, and other options.Storage Analytics can log detailed information for authenticated requests and successful anonymous requests to a storage service. Logging is enabled and disabled at the service level, not the storage account level. To enable logging for the Blob, Table, and Queue services, you must configure each service separately.Note that this cmdlet is not supported for use against the local storage emulator.
Specifies the service to configure (Blob, Table, or Queue).
Applies only to logging configuration. Indicates whether all delete requests should be logged.
Applies only to logging configuration. Indicates whether all read requests should be logged.
Applies only to logging configuration. Indicates whether all write requests should be logged.
Indicates whether a retention policy for logging is enabled for the storage service.
Indicates the number of days that logging data should be retained.
Indicates whether metrics is enabled for the storage service.
Applies only to metrics configuration. Indicates whether metrics should generate summary statistics for called API operations.
Indicates whether a retention policy for metrics is enabled for the storage service.
Indicates the number of days that metrics data should be retained.
Specifies the connection string to connect with the storage.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Not supported for this cmdlet.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.
Specifies the service to configure (Blob, Table, or Queue).
Applies only to logging configuration. Indicates whether all delete requests should be logged.
Applies only to logging configuration. Indicates whether all read requests should be logged.
Applies only to logging configuration. Indicates whether all write requests should be logged.
Indicates whether a retention policy for logging is enabled for the storage service.
Indicates the number of days that logging data should be retained.
Indicates whether metrics is enabled for the storage service.
Applies only to metrics configuration. Indicates whether metrics should generate summary statistics for called API operations.
Indicates whether a retention policy for metrics is enabled for the storage service.
Indicates the number of days that metrics data should be retained.
Specifies the connection string to connect with the storage.
Specifies the name of the storage account. A storage account provides access to storage via the Windows Azure Blob, Queue, and Table services.
Specifies the key of the storage account. The key is unique to a storage account and authenticates access to the account.
Not supported for this cmdlet.

A credentials object from the Windows Azure Storage Client library. This parameter is used for authentication and is primarily used when composing a chain of commands that operate on the storage account.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command configures the Windows Azure Storage Analytics properties of the Blob service in the specified account to enable logging for Delete and Write requests and sets the retention policy for logging to 7 days. The command also enables metrics, including API calls, and sets the retention policy for metrics to 5 days.

maml:description.maml:para: Initiates an in-place upgrade of the specified deployment.
Name of role to upgrade.
Package location. This parameter should have the path or URI to a .cspkg in blob storage whose storage account is part of the same subscription/project.
Label name for the new deployment. If not specified, "<Service Name> + <TimeStamp>" will be used as the label by default.
Upgrade mode. Auto | Manual
Service name.

Storage account name. You can use this parameter when the package location is a path from file system. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet uses the service name parameter as storage account name.
Deployment slot (Staging | Production). If not specified, Production slot will be used by default.
Configuration file path. This parameter should specifiy a .cscfg file on disk.
